note.body:
> I've updated the dialog to something like this. Any further suggestions?

Thanks for the great work, visually it looks nice already. There are only two problems. A small one is that the tooltips need to be carried over, best would be as "i" buttons in the row.
The larger issue is that the keyfile selection doesn't allow selecting keyfiles from different directories. To fix this we can stick to the old behavior of only allowing one keyfile per file chooser and then spawning a new widget for the next keyfile to select. This grows the window so that the dialog would have to be scrollable.

Edit: And a nit – the title should not contain a `?` at the end.

Just for reference, this is the GNOME Shell dialog in German. The "Uses key files" checkbox is there because GNOME Shell doesn't have a file picker and the checkbox is a workaround that changes the dialog to instead open GNOME Disks.
So the main difference is that it has the order switched by having the "Volume Configuration" first. I think it's a minor detail but could be relevant if there a many keyfiles that grow the dialog window until it gets scrolled.

![Bildschirmfoto_vom_2024-11-20_22-25-26](/uploads/1981a33ff54c2693d0f2c0cf2a20952c/Bildschirmfoto_vom_2024-11-20_22-25-26.png)
Sure, no problem
Hey, I am unable to test this functionality using the steps you mentioned. Would it be possible for you to test it yourself?

![image.png](/uploads/bcd920f48e4abb2c21498bced569a6bc/image.png)

I've updated the dialog to something like this. Any further suggestions?
Yes, all title should use Title Case (and be short if possible), so that still applies.

`sudo touch /etc/udisks2/tcrypt.conf` and `systemctl restart udisks2` are needed first. Then you can test this with something that holds random data `head -c 1024000 /dev/urandom > rand.img ; gnome-disk-image-mounter rand.img` (or test with a real volume created through `zuluCrypt-cli`).

Note that the dialog you'll first see when loading such a volume is the dialog from GNOME Shell. I even think it would make sense to follow its design more closely for consistency.
Ah, that was the reason, ok. The prototype doesn't hurt and I'll merge, but we can of course remove it when touching this area again.
Would be good to address later, for now I would merge this MR.

Thanks for the work, much better now ;)

I found two other unrelated issues with the dialog:
- It stays open while the resize job runs, but it should close itself already after the action is started.
- When the resize action fully takes away free space (not covered by a partition), the UI shows the old state and does not update until one restarts the program.
I have added a fix for this in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-disk-utility/-/merge_requests/190/diffs?commit_id=05adfee5984e6ab54a86616a4e6f1506fa35614f
Marking as draft as i have only tested the functionality with passwords. PIM and Keyfiles are totally untested right now.

@kailueke what row's are related here? I'm not sure which ones to link.

As for the second point does it still hold now that unlock dialog is not an `AdwAlertDialog` anymore?

Yes, when ported things are ready, it' no problem to let them in. It's also good to figure out the prerequisites such as UDisks/translation/FFI through this.

I think this is ready for review, even though `update_check_option` and `update_entry_option` are not yet functional (as the widget equality check is not implemented). Since neither of them are used yet, I think it would be fine to wait with their full implementation until it's actually needed.

I would prefer to do the GTK4 version with some parts already ported to Rust, since we already have a working (and mostly feature complete) Rust dialog (with a non-functioning C one), as this would allow @cyberphantom52 to focus on other things and we wouldn't have to synchronize changes on both sides.

target_title: edit-filesystem: Use the notify::text signal to update dialog

note.body: We finally fixed the mount/unmount options ^^ @kailueke
Oh i don't plan to do anything rust related until we have a proper GTK4 release. For now i'm fully committed to fixing the bugs in the GTK4 port and have been working towards that in recent MRs.

On second thought, this method is used nowhere in the current release branch. So this method can be just dropped?

Cc: @kailueke
I assume you want `u64::MAX` here?
Should be safe to drop this as it's not used anywhere. We mostly use the `GtkEditable` interface for manuplating text entries now.

Time-wise it's not great for me to have a live meeting. As far as the topic is the transition to Rust I can state here that it would be good to first release a feature-complete and mostly-bug-free Gtk4 version and afterwards do a rewrite. The rewrite should ideally be gradual (whether it's multi-process or FFI) to ensure that `main` is always releasable. While that would be the idea, it might go a bit wrong and we end up in a situation like now where `main` is not releasable but with the Gtk4 port released the pressure is lower. For collaboration on non-ready changes it's also nice to use a shared feature branch through MR targets or direct pushes, so that a larger rewrite parts could happen there while `main` stays releasable - but this only makes sense with good coordination and when it's not growing 'too large' (depending on whether code gets reviewed through MRs targeted on this branch or whether the review happens when merging the feature branch into `main`).

Not sure how much extra work it's going to be but it'd be nice to use language  internal types where applicable. This would definitely need extra work if we start calling rust code from C and vice-versa but should be worth it in the long run when we do the rust port.

No particular reason, I just wasn't sure what inputs the function would receive, so I just did a direct translation from the C code. 
Updated in 9452bfeb9acbccff141a331349aec5c2028cecfd.
@FineFindus @kailueke Would you be available for a meeting this week? I was thinking of slowly transitioning the main disks app to Rust.
Why don't we use `std::path::Path` here?
This has been fixed in earlier MRs + !185

target_title: Disks shows totally incorrect information about partition size
Improved warning for spare ssd blocks rapidly expring

note.body:
How a device measures 'spare' is a red herring. It's the nature of flash
wearout that the curve is highly nonlinear, with a rapid rate of change
close to failure. That applies independent of whether there are spare
blocks. It's a completely unnecessary crisis, and the code should reflect
this - specifically it should take into account the rate of wear, no matter
whether the reported wear is real or vendor-invented. Since the vendor has
no knowledge of the use, their threshold is pretty much irrelevant anyway.

The additional code does not need to be run often - hourly, or even daily,
would be enough, so negligible cost.

For a compute centre with hot spares, the crisis would be a minor nuisance.
For consumer level, it's the kind of hassle that turns people off linux.
Since we're talking about a gnome component, we're talking primarily about
consumers (the compute centre probably doesn't install gnome in the first
place). So it matters!


My case was a Lenovo Yoga 900 laptop. It was five years old and I needed to
replace it anyway. But I would have appreciated a bit more time to do it
in. The five days warning I got didn't even cover the time it took Lenovo
to build and ship the new one (thinkpad: the yoga was a cute idea, but for
my use it was a mistake).

<details><summary>...</summary>

On Thu, Oct 3, 2024 at 12:07 AM Tomáš Bžatek (@tbzatek) < gitlab-issues@gnome.org> wrote:

> Tomáš Bžatek <https://gitlab.gnome.org/tbzatek> commented
> <https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-disk-utility/-/issues/385#note_2237673>:
>
>
> What type of device this is? Sometimes the spare value and threshold are
> vendor-specific as reported by the drive.
>
> There is also different meaning of a 'spare' - for SSD the flash cells are
> close to wearout and the drive may opt to switch itself to readonly; in
> that case you'll be able to recover all the data. Or, in case spare blocks
> are used for reallocation of bad blocks, then it's time to make a backup
> and replace the drive.
>
> —

</details>

Now Bcachefs performance improved

target_title: [Feature request] Display SMART health warnings as they occur via integration with smartd daemon and notify-send

note.body: UDisks has historically provided all necessary SMART data for ATA disks, recently added similar functionality for NVMe drives also. This is done by polling all drives in a specified interval. Listeners can subscribe to D-Bus property change notification. There are several properties in the `org.freedesktop.UDisks2.Drive.Ata` interface to watch for failed attribute count, etc. Currently the `gdusdmonitor.c` code only watches a single `org.freedesktop.UDisks2.Drive.Ata.SmartFailing` property, this can be improved by your suggestion.

target_title: `/etc/fstab` may be missing, and should be created if needed.

note.body: Fixed by https://github.com/storaged-project/udisks/pull/1263

target_title: Mounting a disk with a manual mount point deletes the entire fstab file

note.body: I've tested this locally and it works as expected. It would be crucial to know more details, have your `/etc/fstab` contents before and after the change and perhaps know the exact layout of disks on your system.

target_title: Model name and serial number incorrectly parsed

note.body: Please provide output of `udevadm info /dev/xxx` and `udisksctl dump`.

`bcachefs` mounting should be supported just fine, for basic filesystem operations this is needed first: https://github.com/storaged-project/libblockdev/pull/959

Contributions appreciated.

target_title: GNOME Disks Should Default to /media for Easier Configuration and Better Integration with flatpak

note.body: This can be influenced by UDisks' configure option `--enable-fhs-media`.

target_title: Improved warning for spare ssd blocks rapidly expring

note.body:
What type of device this is? Sometimes the spare value and threshold are vendor-specific as reported by the drive.

There is also different meaning of a 'spare' - for SSD the flash cells are close to wearout and the drive may opt to switch itself to readonly; in that case you'll be able to recover all the data. Or, in case spare blocks are used for reallocation of bad blocks, then it's time to make a backup and replace the drive.

target_title: The UI does not indicate that a disk is in the standby state since udisks 2.8.4->2.9.0 update

note.body: Please retest with UDisks-2.10.90
